title: Beltrami County officially qualifies for Minnesota DACA funds to aid storm recovery

Yahoo is using AI to generate takeaways from this article. This means the info may not always match what's in the article. Reporting mistakes helps us improve the experience. Generate Key Takeaways

Aug. 15—BEMIDJI — Gov. Tim Walz authorized Beltrami County to receive Minnesota's Disaster Assistance Contingency Account (DACA) funding to aid the ongoing recovery caused by the

This development follows a Minnesota Homeland Security and Emergency Management damage assessment, which fell short of qualifying for Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) aid statewide.

To qualify for FEMA, the state needed to clear a $10.7 million threshold. Although Beltrami County damage estimates clock in at $8.3 million, the state as a whole fell short by $800,000.

However, Beltrami County's damage far exceeded the DACA threshold of $109,000. Now, the state will provide a 75% reimbursement toward publicly damaged infrastructure, while the county will cover the rest. Those with damage to private structures must rely on personal insurance and other means.

"Minnesota is committed to supporting communities in Northwest and West Central Minnesota as they recover from June's storms, which brought hurricane-force winds, severe flooding and widespread damage," Walz said in a release. "When I

with the state emergency management team, we witnessed neighbors helping neighbors, demonstrating a resilience that reflects the very best of Minnesota.

"We will continue to stand with them for the long recovery ahead. I want to extend my deepest gratitude to the emergency responders whose tireless work and partnership have been critical to the recovery effort."

If the state qualified for FEMA, the federal government would have provided a 75% reimbursement while the state would be expected to cover the remaining 25%, providing complete relief to individual counties.

Instead, the affected jurisdictions, including White Earth Nation, Cass, Clearwater, Hubbard, Mahnomen, Norman and Todd Counties, will share individual recovery costs with the state.

A release from Beltrami County Emergency Management added that DACA exists for this purpose and was initially developed after a storm ravaged Beltrami County in 2012, causing significant damage, yet not qualifying for federal aid.

Beltrami County now finds itself in the same situation and will use available resources to continue its recovery effort.
summary: Yahoo is using AI to generate takeaways from this article, which may not always match what's in the article, to improve the user experience. This comes as Beltrami County, Minnesota, officially qualifies for Minnesota's Disaster Assistance Contingency Account (DACA) funding to aid in storm recovery efforts. This follows a statewide assessment that fell short of qualifying for Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) aid, but the county exceeded the $109,000 threshold. The state will provide a 75% reimbursement for publicly damaged infrastructure, while the county will cover the remaining costs. The affected jurisdictions will share individual recovery costs with the state.
shortSummary: Beltrami County qualifies for Minnesota's DACA funds for storm recovery, following a state-wide assessment that fell short of the $10.7 million threshold for FEMA aid.
argos_summary: Governor Tim Walz authorized Beltrami County to receive Minnesota’s Disaster Assistance Contingency Account (DACA) funding to help recover from June’s hurricane‑force winds and flooding, after a state damage assessment fell short of the $10.7 million threshold needed for FEMA aid.  Beltrami’s $8.3 million in damage exceeds the DACA threshold of $109,000, so the state will reimburse 75% of publicly damaged infrastructure while the county covers the remainder; private property owners must rely on insurance.  Other affected jurisdictions—including White Earth Nation, Cass, Clearwater, Hubbard, Mahnomen, Norman and Todd Counties—will share recovery costs with the state under the same arrangement.  The move underscores Minnesota’s commitment to support Northwest and West Central communities through the long recovery process.
